questions.text: A 45 y/o male patient is admitted to the ICU following a major road traffic accident, resulting in multiple fractures and abdominal injuries. The patient is currently unable to take oral nutrition. He is expected to require enteral feeding for more than 3 weeks. Imaging studies reveal delayed gastric emptying and significant gastric distension. What is the most appropriate route for enteral nutrition in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Feeding jejunostomy

Explanation:

This trauma patient has delayed gastric emptying with significant gastric distension and requires long-term enteral nutrition for more than 3 weeks. Therefore, feeding jejunostomy is the most appropriate route as it bypasses the stomach, thereby reducing the risk of complications such as aspiration and further gastric distension.



 

Types of Artificial nutritional supports:

 

Nasogastric tube (Option A) & ryles tube (Option B): Indicated when the duration of the feeding requirement is less than 3 weeks and the patient having good gastric emptying.


Feeding gastrostomy (Option C): Indicated when the duration of the feeding requirement is more than 3 weeks and the patient having good gastric emptying.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male involved in a motor vehicle accident has been in the ICU for several days with multiple injuries including head and abdominal trauma. The ICU team is considering starting enteral feeding. Which of the following findings would most likely contraindicate the initiation of enteral nutrition in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Proximal small intestinal fistula

 

Explanantion: Enteral feeding should be avoided in proximal small intestinal fistula as it can lead to increased fistula output, worsening fluid and electrolyte imbalances.

Inflammatory bowel disease (Option A ruled out)

Severe Pancreatitis

(the food particles stimulate the release of pancreatic enzymes, ultimately worsening the symptoms.)

Distal low-output enterocutaneous fistula (Option B ruled out)

GI bleed

questions.text: A 45-year-old male recovering from gastrointestinal surgery is on total parenteral nutrition (TPN). Initially, he was receiving a 2-in-1 TPN formulation. Due to ongoing nutritional needs, the medical team switches him to a 3-in-1 TPN formulation. Which component is newly included in the 3-in-1 formulation that was not in the 2-in-1?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lipids

Explanation:

In a 3-in-1 TPN, lipids are included along with dextrose and amino acids, which are present in 2-in-1 TPN.

 

TPN Formulations:

 

3 in 1 formulation

2 in 1 formulation

Solutions without lipids

  • 20% by amino acids
  • 20% by fat.

75/25

  • 75% by dextrose (OPTION B ruled out)
  • 25% by amino acids (OPTION A ruled out)
  • No lipids used (OPTION C)

questions.text: A 72-year-old male with severe pancreatitis is initiated on total parenteral nutrition (TPN) due to his inability to tolerate enteral feeding. Shortly after the central venous catheter is inserted, he complains of sudden onset shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain. On examination, his breath sounds are decreased on the same side of the catheter insertion. What is the most likely complication that has occurred?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pneumothorax

 

Explanation: Sudden onset of symptoms after central venous catheter insertion for TPN with decreased breath sounds on the same side of insertion site are pointing towards pneumothorax.

 

Complications of Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN)

 

Line Insertion Complications
  • Pneumothorax (most dangerous)
  • Misplacement of catheter

Line-Related Complications
  • Sepsis (most common)
  • Thrombosis (more common with long-term catheter use)
  • Electrolyte imbalances (e.g., refeeding syndrome)

Metabolic Complications
  • Blood sugar derangements (hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia)
  • Liver dysfunction
  • Metabolic bone disease
  • Vitamin deficiencies

questions.text: A 45 year old male severely malnourished patient with a history of chronic alcoholism and recent weight loss is admitted in the hospital. After stabilization, he is started on a high-calorie enteral feeding regimen to address his nutritional deficiencies. Within 48 hours of initiating feeding, he begins to have muscle weakness, difficulty in breathing and is confused. Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities in the blood is least likely to be associated with his current condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hypernatremia

Explanation:

In this scenario, the likely diagnosis is refeeding Syndrome, which can cause shifts in electrolytes as the body transitions from a catabolic to an anabolic state. Hence, hypernatremia is not commonly associated with refeeding syndrome.

 

Refeeding syndrome:

  • One of the most significant metabolic complications of both parenteral and enteral feeding.
  • This occurs in the first days after feeding is commenced in patients who have been severely malnourished.

The patient is considered to be at risk of developing refeeding syndrome with EITHER

 

One or more of the following: (OR)

Two or more of the following:

BMI <16 kg/m2

BMI <18.5 kg/m2

Unintentional weight loss >15% within the last 3-6 months

Unintentional weight loss >10% within the last 3-6 months.

Little or no nutritional intake for more than 10 days

Little or no nutritional intake for more than 5 days.

Low potassium, phosphate or magnesium levels prior to feeding

History of alcohol abuse or on medication, including insulin, chemotherapy, antacids or diuretics.

 

Mechanism of Refeeding Syndrome:

Electrolyte abnormalities:

  • Hypophosphatemia, (Option A ruled out)
  • Hypomagnesemia, (Option C ruled out)
  • Hypokalemia, (Option B ruled out)
  • Hypocalcemia

Lead to arrhythmia, confusion, and respiratory failure, ultimately leading to death.

 

Management:

  • Matching the intake with requirements.
  • Avoid overfeeding
  • Calorie delivery should be increased slowly
  • Vitamin administration (Thiamine): Given before feeding.
  • Electrolyte abnormalities should be corrected

questions.text: A 30-year-old female undergoes an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy, during which the surgeon uses Vicryl sutures to close the internal fascial layers. Postoperatively, the patient expresses concern about how long the sutures will remain in her body before being fully absorbed. What is the expected time frame for complete absorption of the Vicryl sutures in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 60 - 90 days

 

Explanation: Complete absorption of vicryl sutures occurs in 60–90 days.

 

Vicryl suture (Polyglactin):

  • Braided, multifilament and absorbable suture.
  • Raw material: Copolymer of lactide and glycolide in a ratio of 90:10, coated with polyglactin and calcium stearate.
  • Tensile strength retention in vivo:
    • 60% remains at 2 weeks
    • 30% remains at 3 weeks
  • Absorption rate:
    • By hydrolysis
    • Complete absorption 60–90 days (Option A)
  • Mild tissue reaction
  • Uses:
    • Gut anastomoses, vascular ligatures.
    • ‘workhorse’ suture in most general surgery.
    • Subcuticular wound closures.
    • Ophthalmic surgery.
    • Used in organs that have a high risk of stone formation:
      • CBD
      • Ureter
      • Bladder

 

180 days (Option B): Polydioxanone suture is completely absorbed in 180 days.

 

90 - 120 days (Option C): Polyglycaprone is completely absorbed in 90 - 120 days.

 

7 - 10 days (Option D): Catgut undergoes enzymatic degradation within 7 to 10 days.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male undergoes repair of a laceration on his forearm following a minor accident. The surgeon chooses monocryl for the subcutaneous layer and polyglycolic acid sutures for the deep dermal layer.

Which of the following statements is/are true regarding these sutures in this case?


	Polyglycaparone is preferred over monocryl for subcuticular suturing
	Monocryl is a polymer of glycolide and caprolactone
	Polyglycolic acid exhibits highest affinity for adherence to E.coli and staph. aureus
	Patient is informed that monocryl will be completely absorbed in 180 days
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2 and 3

 

Explanation:

 

Monocryl suture (Polyglycaprone):

  • Raw material: Copolymer of glycolite and caprolactone. (Statement 2)
  • Monofilament
  • Absorption rate: 90–120 days (Statement 4 ruled out).
  • Tensile strength retention in vivo: 21 days maximum
  • Mild tissue reaction
  • Uses: Subcuticular in skin (most commonly used(Statement 1 ruled out) ), ligation, gastrointestinal, and muscle surgery.

Polyglycolic acid suture (DEXON):

  • It is a polymer of glycolic acid
  • Polyfilament suture
  • Absorbed by hydrolysis
  • Maintain sufficient tension over the first 2 weeks
  • Exhibits highest affinity for adherence to E.coli and staph. aureus (Statement 3).

questions.text: A 45-year-old female undergoes an abdominal hysterectomy. The surgeon chooses to close the rectus sheath using PDS (polydioxanone) sutures due to their prolonged tensile strength. What is the expected time frame for the complete absorption of the polydioxanone sutures in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 180 days

 

Explanation: Complete absorption of polydioxanone sutures occurs in 180 days.

Polydioxanone (PDS):

  • Raw material: Para-dioxanone polymer
  • Monofilament
  • Absorption rate: Complete absorption at 180 days (Option B)
  • Mild tissue reaction
  • Tensile strength retention in vivo:
    • 70% remains at 2 weeks
    • 50% remains at 4 weeks
    • 14% remains at 8 weeks
  • Uses: Instances where slightly longer wound support is required
  • Lowest affinity for adherence to E.coli and staph. aureus

 

60 - 90 days (Option A): Complete absorption of vicryl sutures occurs in 60–90 days (Option A).

 

90 - 120 days (Option C): Polyglycaprone is completely absorbed in 90 - 120 days (Option C).

 

7 - 10 days (Option D): Catgut undergoes enzymatic degradation within 7 to 10 days (Option D).

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a history of peripheral artery disease presents with critical limb ischemia. She is scheduled for a femoral-popliteal bypass surgery to restore blood flow to her lower extremity. Which suture is preferred for vascular anastomosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Prolene

 

Explanation: Prolene is the least thrombogenic suture material and is often used in vascular surgery.

 

Prolene (Polypropylene):

  • Raw material: Polymer of propylene
  • Monofilament.
  • Low tissue reaction
  • Tensile strength: Infinite (>1 year)
  • Least thrombogenic suture material
  • Uses: Cardiovascular surgery- vascular anastomosis (Option A), plastic surgery, rectus sheath, ophthalmic, surgery, general surgical subcuticular skin closure.
  • Disadvantages:
    • Has strong memory- poor knot security
    • Lack of elasticity

Silk (Option B): Skin suturing

 

Vicryl (Option C): CBD, ureter and bladder


Nylon (Option D): Tendon repair

questions.text: Which of the following best describes Jenkins's rule in the context of abdominal wound closure?

choices.text: Use of interrupted sutures with bites 2 cm apart to reduce wound tension.
Continuous suturing with bites 1 cm apart, avoiding suture locking to create a "spring coil" effect.
Continuous suturing with locking sutures, with bites placed 1 cm from the wound edge
Use of mattress sutures to maximize the tension across the wound during healing

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Continuous suturing with bites 1 cm apart, avoiding suture locking to create a "spring coil" effect.

 

Explanation:

Jenkins's rule involves continuous suturing with bites that are 1 cm apart and no more than 1 cm from the previous bite, without locking the sutures to allow for a "spring coil" effect that manages wound tension during healing.

Jenkins's Rule in Abdominal Wound Closure:

Purpose: Optimizes healing and manages wound distension post-midline laparotomies.

Technique:

  • Suturing Method: Continuous sutures with bites at least 1 cm apart and no more than 1 cm from the previous bite. (Option B) (Options A & D ruled out)
  • Suture Characteristics: Avoids locking sutures to create a "spring coil" effect, reducing tension during healing. (Option C ruled out)

Physiological Basis:

  • Collagen Focus: Targets type I collagen, abundant around 1 cm from the rectus sheath edge.
  • Healing Enhancement: Leverages the natural properties of tissue for improved wound closure.

questions.text: Which of the following is the recommended knot for securing the final stitch in a continuous suture technique during surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Aberdeen knot

 

Explanation:

Aberdeen knot is specifically used to secure the final stitch in continuous suture techniques.

Continuous sutures involve using a single length of suture material to create multiple stitches, and the Aberdeen knot is effective at securing the end of this continuous line of sutures.

It provides a secure closure and is particularly useful for finishing a continuous suture, ensuring the stitches remain tight and secure.

 

Common Characteristics of Surgical Knots:

  • Firmly tied: Prevents slippage.
  • Small size: Minimizes foreign material in the body.
  • Preserves circulation: Avoids cutting off blood flow to tissues.
  • Undamaged materials: Ensure suture materials aren’t harmed while tying.

Knotting techniques:

  • Granny/ Slip Knots: A knot used to fasten a rope or line around an object, often deemed less dependable than the reef knot.
  • Square/ Reef knot: It is a standard knot with an extra throw for security. (Option A ruled out)
  • Surgeon’s Knot: Extra security, prevents slippage (two-throw knot).(Option C ruled out)
  • Aberdeen Knot: Secures final knot in continuous sutures. (Option B)
  • Buried Knot: Used to secure the ends of absorbable sutures when a subcuticular suture technique is used to close the skin. (Option D ruled out)
  • Monofilament Sutures: Require six throws for secure tying; leave 1–2 mm ends to prevent unraveling.

Types of Suture Techniques and Knots

Knot Used

Tied like standard knots.

Continuous Sutures

Used to evert or invert wound edges. Tied like interrupted sutures.

Tied like standard knots.

Placed under the epidermis for a cosmetic result, using absorbable sutures if needed.

questions.text: Which of the following types of surgical needles is most appropriate for suturing tough or dense tissue such as skin and fascia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Triangular needle

 

Explanation:

Triangular needles have cutting edges along all three sides, making them suitable for penetrating tough or dense tissues like skin and fascia.

Surgical Needles:

  • Atraumatic (Eyeless) Needles:
    • Commonly used in modern surgery.
    • The suture material is embedded within the shank.
  • Proper Grasping:
    • The needle should be grasped by the needle holder about one-third from the rear to avoid damaging the shank or point.

Parts of a Surgical Needle:

  • Shank: The portion held by the needle holder.
  • Body: The main portion that passes through the tissue.
  • Point: The sharp end that penetrates the tissue.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient is undergoing ileostomy closure and the surgeon opts for a hand-sewn anastomosis technique. Which of the following accurately describes the single-layer hand-sewn anastomosis technique?

choices.text: It includes an inner continuous suture layer and an outer layer of interrupted sutures.
It uses a continuous suture line through all layers of the bowel wall, except the mucosa.
It uses a continuous suture line through all layers of the bowel wall.
It involves placing a purse-string suture on the distal stump and stapling the anastomosis.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It uses a continuous suture line through all layers of the bowel wall, except the mucosa.

 

Explanation:

The single-layer hand-sewn anastomosis involves using a continuous suture line that spans through all layers of the bowel wall except the mucosa. This technique is chosen for its simplicity and potentially lower risk of leakage due to fewer suture lines.

Hand-Sewn Anastomosis

Technique

Description

Material Used

Advantages and Risks

Single layer Anastomosis

Continuous suture line, all layers except mucosa (Option B) (Option A & C ruled out)

Monofilament absorbable

Or

Vicryl.

Potentially lower risk of leakage

Double Layer Anastomosis

Inner continuous layer (Albert layer) + outer interrupted sutures (Lembert layer)

Inner layer: Vicryl

Outer layer: Silk

Traditional method with additional support from the outer layer.

Risk: Potential for stricture formation.

 

Stapled Anastomosis: Techniques:

  • Method 1: The proximal bowel is opened, and an anvil stem is deployed through the side of the bowel. The bowel is then stapled shut.
  • Method 2: A purse-string suture is placed on the distal stump. The anvil is tied to this suture, and the trocar and anvil are mated through the proximal bowel. (Option D ruled out)
  • Optimal Side Limb Length:
    • 3-6 cm
